SourcedStatement: Advice from the CDC if you believe someone has been electrocuted
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Look first.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Don't touch.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: The person may still be in contact with the electrical source.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Touching the person may pass the current through you.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Call or have someone else call 911 or emergency medical help.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Turn off the source of electricity if possible.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: If not, move the source away from you and the affected person using a nonconducting object made of cardboard, plastic or wood.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Once the person is free of the source of electricity, check the person's breathing and pulse.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: If either has stopped or seems dangerously slow or shallow, begin cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) immediately.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: If the person is faint or pale or shows other signs of shock, lay him or her down with the head slightly lower than the trunk of the body and the legs elevated.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Don't touch burns, break blisters, or remove burned clothing.
Name: CDC

SourcedStatement: Electrical shock may cause burns inside the body, so be sure the person is taken to a doctor.
Name: CDC
